author: Joanna Mather
title: John 'Wacca' Williams wants GST on fresh food
text:
Senator John Williams says the GST base should be broadened and payroll tax abolished by Joanna Mather Plain-speaking Nationals senator John "Wacca" Williams reckons the GST should be applied to fresh food, education and health to raise enough money to abolish payroll tax.
He says the $22 billion in extra revenue generated by broadening the base of the GST could be used to get rid of payroll tax, which is a hand-break on employment and even forcing businesses to look offshore.
Senator Williams has joined a long line of observers in telling the government's tax review that New Zealand taxes 96 per cent of consumption while Australia only taxes 49 per cent.
"In general terms the GST is not imposed on most basic (fresh) food, education and health," he writes in the only publicly available submission to the tax review by a federal politician.
"The cost of healthcare and education in particular are forever increasing and the Commonwealth and the States are often at loggerheads over who should bear the financial burden.
"Widening the GST is predicted to mean an annual increase of $22 billion in Commonwealth revenue."
Senator Williams is well known for his outspoken views about the big banks and has called for a royal commission into white collar crime in the wake of financial planning scandals.
He said the money recouped from broadening the base of the GST should be used to get rid of state-based payroll taxes.
 "At least one growing NSW business has told me it is now considering outsourcing its work to overseas because of the payroll tax it is forced to pay which adds significantly to its costs," Senator Williams writes.
"While all governments trumpet good employment figures, the hidden factor is the financial burden placed on many businesses because they employ people.
"I believe payroll tax is a blight on the Australian economy and needs to be addressed. Broadening the base of the goods and services tax is one way this can be done."
The ACT announced in its May budget that it would slash payroll tax for small business and axe stamp duty on business insurances, while NSW Small Business Minister John Barilaro says that state needs to work towards scrapping the tax.
